Comment: In Roe v. Wade, a national right to abortion was established through a specific legal concept called substantive due process. This is the legal concept that was discussed and rejected for abortion in Dobbs. It would be reasonable for someone to apply the Dobbs precedent to other substantive due process rights, yes, but it would not really make sense to apply that precedent to anything else.  You're basically oversimplifying. It wasn't that abortion was overturned because it's not in the Constitution. It's overturned because the Court rejected the premises of substantive due process which protects rights not explicitly mentioned in the Constitution.   So no, you could not use Dobbs to justify secession, but you could use it to justify taking away federal protections on interracial marriage, for example.

Comment: Nothing is really settled law, everything is subject to judicial review as the Supreme Court, being made of humans, is fallable and sometimes makes mistakes or views constitutionality in inappropriate ways that later Supreme Court benches might not think holds up.  The military appropriations clause has had a bit of a weird view about it. There's a reason the National Defense Authorization Act which comes up generally every year or every other year is considered must pass.  https://www.law.cornell.edu/constitution-conan/article-1/section-8/clause-11%E2%80%9314/time-limit-on-appropriations-for-the-army  https://law.justia.com/constitution/us/article-1/55-the-power-to-raise-and-maintain-armed-forces.html   If you really want to get high quality and detailed answers you might want to go to a focused subreddit like r/supremecourt
